we have cloud storage uh on s3 that's called uh where we uh receive the
what we call the ingest logs so from our analytics supplier they deliver us file

there's a new file that has been received and is ready for processing so this event goes into a queue okay so
many events will be lined up in that in that queue and then there is a java application that we call the job submitter
that will read each one of those events validate the name of a file that is
something that we actually expected to receive but it's essentially very very minimal stuff that it does and then
it passes on to the next one on the chain and this is not really not really so
much of microservices it's actually a mapreduce a mapreduce cluster but what this does is it can
process multiple files at a time and what it does it actually goes into the contents of it file
and validates that validates them against the model okay so we do what we
call model driven validation and this model kind of defines what are the different fields
that are expected in file what are accepted values if not it will reject the file and
notify us and it also compresses data when it's written
to the next chain and it also does what we call enrichments which are essentially transformations on some of those fields
the fields can contain locations they can contain postcodes they can contain
dates and times and sometimes the format that they come in is not the most useful so they're
actually transformed and and then written out and then these files are stored in what
we call the intermediate data lake we call intermediate only because it's for
use within this microservices architecture our users of the data they
don't have access to the we we call it it's still in a bit of a raw format even
though it's invalidated it's not in the most optimum way to be kind of queried and analyzed on
so there's another process down the line called the data summaries and what this does is it takes those
files and it knows a bit more about the data and about the expected use
that reports or dashboards or data analysts will make of it and it does aggregations
and summaries and those aggregations and summaries are then written out to our data warehouse
and for that we we use amazon.chief and it's essentially a big data database and
it can it does perform queries at scale and then the historical archive of the
data ends up in the data lake okay in fact if we keep a subset of that
data because that's normally the the use cases we've had and they will be you know

will probably happen over time that you won't know about so
by catering for these known unknowns the question is do you have enough information

so there's another mode of failures uh and these are called
unknown unknowns what these are is well
we know every system will will fail at some point every every production system

so let's go back to architecture and the known the known unknowns that we
learned from and we designed for when we were designing the architecture and i've summarized them in this table
the first one of them was well things used to fail in a big bang fashion and we used to just kind of lose
a whole day's processing of data and this was very painful because when you're working at a scale of billions
then it's harder to recover it's harder to investigate everything is just you
know more difficult so in this case we said we have to be able
to isolate failure okay so each one of the microservices that is made up in the architecture if it comes down
or we have to investigate that we have to take it out of the processing chain then it doesn't affect the others okay
they can operate independently and that's been a huge huge bonus the second issue was
well we encounter issues and we find that we just don't have enough data to
investigate them we look at the logs we look at the metrics but this is still there's no conclusive um
kind of thing that we can say about what's caused the failure so in the data space
there's a term called lineage store and what is this what this is is essentially
being able to track all the data that you receive and that goes through your system and the different stages
that it goes through so that if anything happens you are able to kind of go into this
historical archive of events and see at which point things failed
okay the third one goes back into kind of failure and the ability to play
so we have built some utilities in our new architecture
that help us replace data okay and this happens at various stages
of the processing chain and has been tremendously useful and made our lives really easier and then the fourth one is it's just
being able to answer a simple question in a distributed system sometimes it's just not that straightforward so
you have to always focus how do you know that things are running like do you really know
if things are running and in this case we still have metrics we still have dashboards
but the lineage store has given us that added granularity that we needed um to be able to kind of
answer that question on a more detailed level so let's go to architecture

number three is the ability to replay data so we have that utility

for missing files and if there are any missing files it will alert us but also it will create
a ticket open an incident ticket with our supplier and give them the exact

the second the second thing that kind of has come up over time is that when you operate um

about what is the kind of the availability the promise availability of your service but

what is kind of your promise for fixing them okay and in our case um
we have that like every other live product and we have the data in the
